sections.heading: TOXICOLOGY AND COMPATIBILITY WITH BIOANALYTES
sections.text:
The use of 2D materials in biomedical applications may necessitate a close interaction between 2D layers and biological cells, as in in vivo devices/assays (such as neural interfacing or theranostics), wearable technologies, and optogenetics. Thus, it is important to understand the interactions between materials used in devices/assays and the bioanalytes (cells and biofluids). Toxicology of 2D Materials. 2D materials can affect cells
chemically, mechanically, or electrochemically, potentially making them incompatible with each other.304 Chemical effects refer to atoms or molecules that are released in the presence of cells. These species may be a result of decomposition of the material or a release of bioactive molecules.304 Mechanical interactions are reliant on the structure, bending stiffness, and hydrophobicity of the sheets and are of central importance. 2D materials can orient themselves in multiple ways outside, around, across, or inside of the cell membrane (Figure 9a).304 Such interactions may stress the cell or may be entirely benign depending on the circumstance.305 The third type of interaction with cells is electrochemical, which refers to the catalytic properties of 2D materials. Particularly important is the generation of ROS through redox reactions which can induce oxidative stress in cells and is thought to be a leading cause of cytotoxicity for many engineered nanomaterials.306 A thorough discussion of the biocompatibility of 2D materials warrants a standalone
review, and hence, we refer the readers to the following references for more in-depth analyses.306−312
As previously discussed, TMDs can be found in a variety of structures, layer number, phases, synthesis techniques, and elemental composition. Therefore, when utilizing TMDs (and other 2D materials) in devices or assays, we must consider all of these factors when determining a material to be biocompatible or bio-incompatible (i.e., toxic).313 The biocompatibility of three of the most common TMDs (MoS2, WS2, and WSe2) was examined by Teo et al., who utilized exfoliated TMDs with lung epithelial cells (A549).314
The authors found that WSe2 exhibited higher cytotoxicity than either WS2 or MoS2, which was attributed to the toxic effects of Se. Following this study, the same group examined the role of the chalcogen atom in the biocompatibility of exfoliated vanadium dichalcogenides (VS2, VSe2, and VTe2). 315 All three materials exhibited a concentration-dependent decrease in the cell viability of A549 cells. However, VS2 appeared less toxic than VSe2 and VTe2, suggesting that the chalcogen atom may play an important role in determining the biocompatibility of TMDs. The same cell line was used to study the toxicity of group 5 (Ta, V, Nb) ditellurides.316 Here, the authors found a dose-dependent toxicity of VTe2 and concluded this TMD to be highly toxic. In contrast, NbTe2 and TaTe2 were shown to exhibit only mild toxicity (although more toxic than MoS2 and WS2), with ∼65% cell viability (compared to ∼10% for VTe2) at a high TMD concentration of 200 μg/mL. The higher toxicity of VTe2 was hypothesized
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.9b03632 ACS Nano 2019, 13, 9781−9810
9796
to be a result of increased ROS generation, which can induce oxidative stress in cells. The biocompatibility of graphene and its analogues has also been well-studied as these materials find their place in biosensors and other healthcare applications. Graphene-based sensors have already been utilized in direct contact with human skin by Kabiri Ameri et al. with no adverse side effects reported, implying some degree of biocompatibility.256,257 In contrast, in a study using neuronal cells (PC12), Zhang et al. reported a concentration-dependent cytotoxicity of unbound graphene (synthesized using catalyst-assisted CVD), which was attributed to oxidative stress and apoptosis.317 Graphene actually appeared more toxic at lower concentrations compared to single-walled carbon nanotubes, whereas the trend reversed at higher concentrations. An important note to make about cytotoxicity studies of nanomaterials is the choice of viability assay, which has been shown to play a role in inconsistent results. For example, Liao and co-workers studied the cytotoxicity of GO and rGO sheets (synthesized via a hydrazine-free Hummers’ method) for both red blood cells (RBCs) and human skin fibroblast cells using two different assays.318 For the fibroblast cells, both GO and rGO were found to be cytotoxic according to the WST-8 assay, whereas neither were found to be cytotoxic with the methylthiazolyldiphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay. The authors showed that the MTT assay was reacting with the material without any cells present, confirming their hypothesis that the MTT assay was overestimating viability. In RBCs, it was observed that both GO and rGO sheets caused hemolysis (i.e., destruction of RBCs) in a dose-dependent manner, although the rGO was found to be less hemolytic due to fewer oxygen groups on the surface. A similar result was seen by Singh et al., who studied the effect of GO and rGO on platelet aggregation.319 GO was found to cause severe platelet aggregation, which decreased in the case of rGO, demonstrating the crucial role of surface charge and chemistry when evaluating biocompatibility. In vitro studies of GO in human corneal and conjunctiva (hConECs and hCorECs, respectively) cells revealed shortterm (∼24 h) cytotoxic effects.320 Eye-based sensors are an up and coming area, especially in technologies such as smart contact lenses, making in vivo studies critical for progress in commercialization. In vivo studies with mice revealed reversible cytotoxic effects upon repeated exposure of GO to the eye over 5 days, which were attributed to ROS-induced oxidative stress. That said, there are discrepancies in the cytotoxicity of graphene or GO, as other reports describe little to no cytotoxic effects.272,321−323 For example, in a separate in vivo study on the ocular toxicity of GO, Yan et al. found little to no change in eyeball appearance, intraocular pressure, or histological response in rabbits.323 However, they performed in vitro studies on human retinal pigment cells and noted some slight cytotoxicity, indicating more biocompatibility studies are needed. Chang et al. found GO (by modified Hummers’ method) to show little cytotoxic effects on A549 cells, based on the CCK-8 assay (which uses WST-8).321 Another study by Sahni et al. also found graphene (catalyst-assisted CVD growth) to show slightly better cell viability and lower lactate dehydrogenase (LDH, indicative of membrane integrity)324 activity than standard cell culture dishes when studying neuronal cells from mice.272 The discrepancies in reported toxicity described in the previous examples elucidate the importance of degrees of freedom, surface chemistry, particle
size, shape, synthesis technique, assay, and even cell line, when evaluating the biocompatibility of nanomaterials, including carbon-based materials.306,307,310,311,325
Aside from TMDs and carbon-based materials, the biocompatibility of other members of the 2D family, such as h-BN, MXenes, and black phosphorus are less-explored.307 hBN has generally been found to exhibit relatively good biocompatibility.326−329 McManus et al. prepared a variety of 2D material water-based inks and studied their biocompatibility with A549 and HaCaT cell lines.326 They found no decline in viability even at h-BN concentrations up to 100 μg/ mL. In contrast, Liu et al. began to see a slight decrease in the viability in HepG2 cells at concentrations of ∼25 μg/mL, as well as cell membrane damage determined via LDH assay at concentrations >0.5 μg/mL.330 Black phosphorus (BP) has been shown to exhibit toxic effects to varying degrees.331−333 Zhang et al. systematically investigated the size-dependent biocompatibility of solution-exfoliated BP sheets with three different cell lines (NIH 3T3, HCoEpiC, and 293T).333 They found a clear concentration- and size-dependent trend in cytotoxicity, where the smallest flakes (∼275 nm) showed relatively mild cytotoxicity versus the largest flakes (∼1100 nm), which showed very high cytotoxicity (in 293T cells, 0% viability after 24 h with 6.25 μg/mL). Additionally, the biocompatibility was found to be highly dependent on the cell line. In another study of the size dependence on biocompatibility, Fu et al. found little cytotoxic effects in their BP sheets, although the flake sizes studied were all under 400 nm.334 MXenes are quickly finding a place in healthcare applications, such as theranostics and photothermal therapy (as discussed in the “Emerging Technologies” section), although there are few systematic studies on their biocompatibility. Dai and coworkers designed a MnOx/Ti3C2 composite and found the viability of 4T1 cells remained around 100% after 2 days at concentrations up to 100 μg/mL.335 Additional reports show similar results for Ti3C2, 336,337 as well as Ta4C3 279,338 and Nb2C. 339 These results provide early verification of the biocompatibility of the MXene family, although eventually studies on human subjects, rather than mice, are needed before industry adoption of these materials in in vivo biosensing and photothermal therapy. By understanding the three mechanisms of interaction listed above (chemical, mechanical, and electrochemical), it is possible to design nanomaterials to suit a specific application, either by making them safer for certain cells or more toxic for others (like cancer cells). Considering the complex interplay of variables, it is worth investigating the biocompatibility of 2D materials on a case-by-case basis. Currently, there remain many unanswered questions and uncertainties regarding the role of 2D material properties in cytotoxicity. This is reflected in many works beginning to look beyond just cellular viability as a sole indicator of biocompatibility. Instead, assays including LDH for evaluating membrane integrity,340 DCFH-DA for ROS analysis,322,341 Alamar Blue for monitoring lymphocyte proliferation,322 comet assay for DNA strand breaking,342 and altered gene expression,340,343−345 among others, are being utilized to provide a deeper understanding of the growth environment and immune response in the presence of nanomaterials. Furthermore, studies into chronic, long-term exposure to these materials would certainly be worthwhile in helping to transition technology from the laboratory phase into the consumer market. Many of the reported studies examine acute or short-term exposure, rather than long-term (i.e., years
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.9b03632 ACS Nano 2019, 13, 9781−9810
9797
or decades), which is understandable as graphene was first isolated only 15 years ago. Antifouling Properties. In order to realize commercially viable biosensors, including those utilizing 2D materials, accurate detection of target analytes in complex physiological media (e.g., blood, saliva, or interstitial fluid) is necessary. Due to the abundance of nontarget species in these media, there is an additional complication known as biofouling.346−348 As the sensor is exposed to a biofluid, unwanted molecules and other species (e.g., proteins, bacteria, platelets, etc.) can accumulate on the surface, thereby interfering and degrading the sensor’s capabilities. In order to combat this, techniques including microtexturing of the surface,349 polymer coating,350−352 and formation of superhydrophobic surfaces353,354 are commonly employed. Interestingly, 2D materials can exhibit antifouling properties, which can further facilitate their application as sensing materials for testing in complex media, membranes in water filtration, and protective coatings.355,356,365,357−364 Many reports on antifouling are based on GO, although a recent report by Alam et al. showed that MoS2 generally has antifouling capabilities better than those of GO when tested with natural organic matter (NOM) and E. coli cells.355 Here, the deposition rate of the NOM and bacteria on the 2D materials was studied using a quartz crystal microbalance. The high zeta-potential of both materials made them repel NOM (negatively charged) very well, whereas the MoS2 proved slightly better than GO due to the lack of functional groups on the surface. The presence of monovalent and divalent cations in solution lowered the antifouling properties of both materials due to charge neutralization and salt bridging. In a separate report by Hang et al., a vertical graphene/ZnO nanorod (vG/ NR) sensor was designed for detection of H2O2.
354 By fluorinating the vG/NR, little to no platelet adhesion was seen when testing in serum, which enabled a consistent response to H2O2 when reusing the sensor. That said, when tested with H2O2 in a more concentrated blood solution (20% vs 1% v/v in PBS), the hydrophobicity, and thus the antifouling properties, was reduced, implying more work is needed before the sensor can serve in real-world applications. Antibacterial Effects. In healthcare, the ability to sanitize various surfaces (such as medical implants, surgical tools, catheters, or food/water reservoirs) are of tantamount importance, especially in medical care, food safety, and environmental monitoring. The disinfection of drinking water is an especially pressing problem in developing countries around the world.366 There exists a definite need for improved sanitation methods and antimicrobial coatings that are lowcost, low-power, high-efficiency, and environmentally friendly.367 Growing research focus has been given to nanomaterials in order to fill this technological void. Among them, 2D materials are promising candidates due to their favorable antibacterial properties368 and high specific surface area. Additionally, the 2D materials can be coupled with existing approaches to improve current sanitation practices.367 Two important figures of merit in developing sanitation strategies include the minimization of bacterial inactivation time and maximization of inactivation yield. For solution-based sanitation methods, one way of recovering/recycling the 2D material after use is to attach magnetic materials. Zhang et al. demonstrated a ternary composite of GO, nano-Ag, and nanoFe3O4 that achieved high rates of inactivation for both Grampositive and Gram-negative bacteria in relatively short time
periods (∼1 h) at low to medium concentrations (6.25−50 μg/mL).369 The antibacterial properties were attributed to ROS generation and silver ion release. Thanks to the nanoFe3O4, the composites were able to be extracted from solution using an external magnetic field and reused. A work by Wang et al. utilized a different approach by creating a capacitive deionization disinfection (CDID) system suitable for brackish water.370 The device utilized graphene oxide-graf t-quaternized chitosan (GO-QC) deposited on activated carbon electrodes for continuous-flow disinfection, as shown in Figure 9b. Specifically, the chitosan derivative applied to the graphene electrostatically disrupted the bacterial membranes, which were attracted by the positive electrode. At a flow rate of 1 mL/min and bias of 2 V, the authors were able to achieve a 6 log reduction in E. coli viability in water. Moreover, the disinfection percentage was maintained at a consistent level for multiple hours due to a regeneration procedure.

sections.heading: FUTURE AND OUTLOOK
sections.text:
Immense progress has been made in 2D material research since 2004, with an exponential increase in publications each year.371 Healthcare has emerged as a promising avenue for future applications of these materials, considering the significant improvements that they offer compared to the state-of-the-art. Still, commercial products from these efforts are limited, and progress in this area is mostly being pushed forward by small start-up companies.372 Before large-scale and widespread manufacturing of 2D devices for health-related applications can be realized, improvements in synthesis, manufacturing, processing, and integration are necessary. A central issue with any 2D biosensor, particularly in competition with the existing technologies, is a low-cost, yet controllable, material synthesis route. In particular, achieving large-scale uniformity of material properties is essential in order to implement them in mass production, beyond fundamental science research; device-to-device variability could preclude an otherwise exceptional sensor system from reaching consumers. That said, compared with their 0D and 1D counterparts, 2D materials are inherently more compatible with modern fabrication techniques due to their planar nature. Additionally, for flexible bioelectronics with designs requiring small feature size, synthesis/fabrication cost is particularly pressing. The existing 2D materials synthesis methods (such as CVD) that can provide minimal sample-to-sample variation are not compatible with polymeric flexible substrates (due to requiring high-temperature processing); therefore, growth is usually done on a separate substrate and then the 2D layer is transferred.373 The existing transfer methods are highly challenging for high-throughput device fabrication, especially without creating wrinkles and/or defects.373,374 Thus, an important research goal is to either improve/demonstrate the scalability and uniformity of transfer techniques (at low-cost) or enable the synthesis directly onto the final substrate (hence, moving toward lower-temperature synthesis). Other challenges for real-life application of 2D materials in in vivo biomedical areas (such as those discussed above) are biocompatibility and regulation of their environmental stability (both in testing mediums and storage conditions). In many cases, the 2D materials will necessarily come into contact with complex biological environments and these conditions may degrade the device performance over a short time.4 In order to address this issue, systematic investigations of 2D material stability or coating strategies (without sabotaging the sensing
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.9b03632 ACS Nano 2019, 13, 9781−9810
9798
capabilities) are needed. Biofouling has been addressed, to some degree, by coating with polymers or other chemical modification. Antifouling properties of 2D materials have been demonstrated, especially in water filtration applications, and biosensor researchers may employ these properties to combat biofouling in more complicated media. Furthermore, as 2D materials find their role in point-of-care diagnostics and in vivo applications, a firm understanding of their toxicology/ biocompatibility will be necessary. Tremendous work has been done over the past 10 years in this regard. Of critical importance will be the precise control over the material’s properties and correlating them to the material’s biocompatibility. The cytotoxicity is heavily influenced by morphology, surface chemistry, and synthesis method, among numerous other properties, making universal claims of biocompatibility impossible. However, further study of the mechanisms and the effect of local environment on cell growth in the presence of 2D materials will enable more reliable prediction of cytotoxicity. As the critical technological challenges are addressed, platforms based on 2D materials can offer overarching opportunities for next-generation healthcare technologies. Due to their extreme thinness, transparency, and mechanical strength, 2D platforms could be incorporated into textiles for fitness/health monitoring. Additionally, 2D electronic tattoos could be used as part of virtual/augmented reality systems to monitor and react to user motion/physiological state. The defining feature of these platforms compared to their classical counterparts (e.g., based on thin metal films) is being imperceptible, which turns out to play an important role in the end user’s experience/acceptance. Already, graphene electro-oculography tattoos have been used to direct the motion of a quadcopter. Minor modifications could easily enable responsive programs, from games, to human-machine interfaces, to adaptive technologies. For in vitro diagnostics, 2D material-based sensors for nucleic acids could enable rapid, label-free, and highly sensitive early disease detection. Already, the ability to quantify concentrations down to attomolar range (at least million times better than the state-of-the-art technologies) suggests that 2D biosensors could serve as the foundation of next-generation technology in personalized medicine. The scientific community has made significant progress in 2D materials for biosensing and biomedical applications. Further development and realization of these and many other technologies hinge upon sustained academic research and collaborative efforts with industrial partners to enable nextgeneration biotechnologies for personalized health monitoring, wearable technologies, and low-power, portable diagnostics with superior performance compared to the existing platforms.

metadata.abstractText: Since the isolation of graphene in 2004, there has been an exponentially growing number of reports on layered two-dimensional (2D) materials for applications ranging from protective coatings to biochemical sensing. Due to the exceptional, and often tunable, electrical, optical, electrochemical, and physical properties of these materials, they can serve as the active sensing element or a supporting substrate for diverse healthcare applications. In this review, we provide a survey of the recent reports on the applications of 2D materials in biosensing and other emerging healthcare areas, ranging from wearable technologies to optogenetics to neural interfacing. Specifically, this review provides (i) a holistic evaluation of relevant material properties across a wide range of 2D systems, (ii) a comparison of 2D material-based biosensors to the state-of-the-art, (iii) relevant material synthesis approaches specifically reported for healthcare applications, and (iv) the technological considerations to facilitate mass production and commercialization.
